1:
The words of Agur son of Jakeh—the utterance:\q This man declared to Ithiel, to Ithiel and Ucal:
\f + \ft Some versions have \fqa This man declared, "I am weary, O God, I am weary. I am unable to do anything." \fqa* \f*
\q
2:
Surely I am more like an animal than any human\q and I do not have the understanding of a human being.
\q
3:
I have not learned wisdom,\q nor do I have knowledge of the Holy One.


\q
4:
Who has gone up to heaven and come down?\q Who has gathered up the wind in the hollow of his hands?
\q Who has gathered up the waters in a cloak?
\q Who has established all the ends of the earth?
\q What is his name, and what is the name of his son? Surely you know!
 

\q
5:
Every word of God is tested;\q he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.
\q
6:
Do not add to his words,\q or he will discipline you, 
\q and you will be proved to be a liar.

\q
7:
Two things I ask of you,\q do not withhold them from me before I die:
\q
8:
Put vanity and lies far away from me.\q Give me neither poverty nor riches,
\q just give me the food I need.
\q
9:
For if I have too much, I might deny you and say, "Who is Yahweh?"\q Or if I become poor,
\q I might steal and profane the name of my God.
 

\q
10:
Do not slander a slave before his master,\q or he will curse you and you will be held guilty.


\q
11:
There is a generation that curses their father\q and does not bless their mother.
\q
12:
There is a generation that is pure in their own eyes,\q and yet they are not washed of their filth.


\q
13:
There is a generation whose eyes are raised up,\q and how high are their eyelids lifted up!
\q
14:
There is a generation whose teeth are swords,\q and their jawbones are like knives,
\q so they may devour the poor from the earth and the needy from among humanity.


\q
15:
The leech has two daughters: "Give and give" they cry.\q There are three things that are never satisfied,
\q four that never say, "Enough":
\q
17:
The eye that mocks a father\q and scorns obedience to a mother,
\q his eyes will be pecked out by the ravens of the valley,
\q and he will be eaten by the vultures.


\q
18:
There are three things that are too wonderful for me,\q four that I do not understand:
\q
20:
This is the way of an adulteress:\q she eats and she wipes her mouth
\q and says, "I have done nothing wrong."


\q
21:
Under three things the earth trembles,\q and under four it cannot bear up:
\q
22:
a slave when he becomes king;\q a fool when he is filled with food;
\q
23:
a hated woman when she marries;\q and a maid when she takes the place of her mistress.

\q
24:
Four things on earth are small\q and yet they are very wise:
\q
25:
the ants are creatures that are not strong,\q but they prepare their food in the summer;
\q
26:
the rock badgers are not mighty creatures,\q but they make their homes in the rocks.


\q
27:
Locusts have no king,\q but all of them march in rank.
\q
28:
As for the lizard, you can hold it in your two hands,\q yet they are found in kings' palaces.


\q
29:
There are three things that are stately in their stride\q and four that are stately in how they walk:
\q
30:
a lion, strongest among wild animals—\q it does not turn away from anything;
\q
31:
a strutting rooster; a goat;\q and a king whose soldiers are beside him.


\q
32:
If you have been foolish, exalting yourself,\q or if you have been devising evil—
\q put your hand over your mouth.
\q
33:
As churning milk makes butter\q and as one's nose will produce blood if it is twisted,
\q so deeds done in anger produce conflict.
